abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for Ceará Rural Poverty
            Reduction Project for Brazil were as follows: outcome was
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Ratings
            for Santa Catarina Natural Resources Management Project for
            Brazil were as follows: outcome was satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some of the key lessons learned
            from two projects include: (i) where projects seek
            improvements in incomes and living conditions of the poor, a
            multidimensional approach will help to better define
            objectives and monitor achievements; (ii) a community-driven
            development (CDD) project may not be the best option to
            provide access to last mile public services, such as
            electricity; (iii) reaching the rural poor through a
            community driven development approach requires clear
            participation criteria underpinned by accurate welfare
            knowledge or data and a system of aid allocation that is
            transparent and accounted for by beneficiaries; (iv)
            although productive subproject approaches may have a more
            direct and visible impact on incomes, the provision of
            complementary basic services within or outside of the
            project framework is also key to ensuring sustainability;
            and (v) integrating poverty reduction and natural resource
            management (as in the Santa Catarina project) may be a
            better option than addressing these objectives in a separate project
